Which is more correct:
"Well, Max, do you fill the criteria?"
"Well, Max, do you fit the criteria?"

The correct phrase is "do you fit the criteria?".

"Fill the criteria" is incorrect. The proper idiom is "fit the criteria", meaning to meet or satisfy the criteria.

So in this case, "Well, Max, do you fit the criteria?" would be the proper way to ask that question.

"Fit" is the right word to use here, not "fill".
Couldn't fill be used as a substitute for fulfill?

You make a good point. The words "fill" and "fulfill" are closely related and in some contexts can be used interchangeably. However, in the specific phrase "fit the criteria", "fill" does not work as a substitute for "fulfill".

This is because "criteria" refers to a set of requirements or standards, and something that "fits" them meets or satisfies them. "Fulfill" would imply accomplishing or achieving them, which isn't quite the right meaning.

So while "fill" and "fulfill" are synonyms in some cases, "fit the criteria" is a set phrase where "fit" is the proper word to use. "Fill the criteria" may sound okay, but it is not idiomatically correct in this context.

The bottom line is that word choice in idioms and set phrases can be tricky, even when the words are related. The proper way to use the phrase is "fit the criteria".
